content.body: How would the : separator, without parens, work with typescript?
i guess `when ${x as y}: RHS as z` would be fine, since there's no `:` type declarations there
content.formatted_body: i guess when ${x as y}: RHS as z would be fine, since there's no : type declarations there

content.body: Does TS use colons for something near that syntax space?
Neither : or -> used in ts as I can recall.
Ah, `:` is used in the same way it is in Python, to annotate a variable.
content.formatted_body: Ah, : is used in the same way it is in Python, to annotate a variable.

content.body: I recall yulia wanted us to avoid `->` for TS-adjacent reasons, but I don't remember the details of it. Was it to reserve the space for JS to potentially grow annotations?
content.formatted_body: I recall yulia wanted us to avoid -> for TS-adjacent reasons, but I don't remember the details of it. Was it to reserve the space for JS to potentially grow annotations?

content.body: But yeah, `:` in pattern space would be just fine, it's wouldn't be capable of receiving an annotation.
content.formatted_body: But yeah, : in pattern space would be just fine, it's wouldn't be capable of receiving an annotation.

content.body: Tho hm, I suppose `when a: int: RHS` might be reasonable?
content.formatted_body: Tho hm, I suppose when a: int: RHS might be reasonable?

content.body: not terribly important now, if its an issue they can complain
content.formatted_body: not terribly important now, if its an issue they can complain

 * not terribly important now, if its an issue they can complain

m.new_content.body: not terribly important now, if its an issue they can complain
m.new_content.formatted_body: not terribly important now, if its an issue they can complain

content.body: Oh nice, because `->` is my favorite of all the separators for this case.
content.formatted_body: Oh nice, because -> is my favorite of all the separators for this case.

content.body: (If we do end up with problems, keeping with "parenthesized matcher, no separator" is fine with me, I just think (and iirc mpcsh also feels this way) that a separator is very good for readability, and if we have that we shouldn't need wrapper characters.)
content.formatted_body: (If we do end up with problems, keeping with "parenthesized matcher, no separator" is fine with me, I just think (and iirc mpcsh also feels this way) that a separator is very good for readability, and if we have that we shouldn't need wrapper characters.)

content.body: It uses `:` for variable/field/parameter  declarations and return type annotations,  `<T>x` or `x as T` for casts and `f<T>` for generics
Also, `=>` is used for return type annotations in function and constructor types, but only when you're already in type-space
Yeah `=>` is already a hard-reject from the possibilities, since it has different semantics than arrow function bodies.
content.formatted_body: Yeah => is already a hard-reject from the possibilities, since it has different semantics than arrow function bodies.
